newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Commission says no evidence of NZ air price fixing.
newsitem.headline: Commission says no evidence of NZ air price fixing.

text.p: The New Zealand Commerce Commission said on Wednesday it found no evidence that Ansett New Zealand and Air New Zealand had colluded over recent domestic fare increases.
The two airlines hiked domestic fares by three percent on December 15 and international airlines raised their fares by the same amount that day.
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) had previously recommended a three percent fare hike because of rising fuel prices.
The commission investigated to see if there was a breach of the Commerce Act but found none.
Chairman Alan Bollard warned that if the commission found evidence of price fixing it would act.
"Any form of formal or informal communication among competitors about prices can breach the Act," he said.
"In some cases a firm giving a rival prior warning of a pricing announcement could be enough to be price fixing."
The commission could not investigate the raising of international fares because the rise was authorised by the Transport Ministry following an IATA recommendation.
